course.subject: IEDA
course.name: Engineering Economics and Accounting
course.description: Application of microeconomics to engineering and managerial decision making. Basic accounting cash flow analysis of capital investment. Present worth, rate of return, taxes and depreciation, capital budgeting, cost accounting, risk and uncertainty.

reviews.author: PyothePro
reviews.title: Interesting Course
reviews.comment_content:
Profit and Revenue Maximization, Cash Flow Diagram, Options, Portfolio Management, IRR&ERR, ROSCA, deterministic models, probability models, etc.

They are all very interesting concepts that are worth studying as an Industrial Engineer. However, I'm so disappointed in the way it's taught. The course can be taught in a much more entertaining fashion.

The important skills for this course are "Math" and "Reading" skills.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Our professor seemed to have some level of passion when teaching. Also, he would give us real-life examples and also tell us some of his own interesting life lessons. To be honest, I sincerely believe he is a great person with good intrinsic values.

Apart from this, the teaching part was torture for me. To begin with, I can't ever stay focused in his class because of his monotonous tone. I literally do not remember a single class where I did not fall asleep towards the end. In addition, the IPRS questions are needlessly way too difficult, which does not help when I want to stay awake. For the later parts of the course, I had to search google and discuss with classmates to fully grasp the concepts because his explanations were a bit too....abstract.

The icing on the cake was that I would sometimes ask questions during class via zoom chat, only for the majority of my questions to be ignored. Maybe he thought my questions were pointless :(    (Ouch)

Our TA, Joy, on the other hand, was great. She would give me satisfying explanations whenever I had any questions in the lecture notes.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload can be very light or very heavy depending on who your groupmates are. Luckily, all my groupmates were very hard-working and intelligent individuals who performed well. In particular, there was this one person who really had strong leadership. (Thanks, you know who you are)

The IPRS forces you to attend all lectures, which was the biggest torment in this class for me.

reviews.author: 16y39y
reviews.title: quite confusing
reviews.comment_content:
Topics: cost terminology, profit and revenue maximization, cost driven design, time value of money (cash flows including compounding, annuity, gradient, continuous compounding, equivalent cash flows), IRR&ERR, accounting double entries, project comparisons (deterministic and probabilistic), ROSCA, decision tree, options and portfolio management.

I personally enjoyed the topics themselves, but they were taught in such an odd approach. For examples, instead of going over the formula for the cash flows, the Professor encouraged to use some specific notation to check values from a 30-page long table. I suppose he doesn't want to overwhelm us with the derivation and stuff, but the notation can become very confusing sometimes. Other topics, like Options and Portfolio management, were very enjoyable as well. But due to the packed teaching schedule, he skimmed over options way too quickly in one class and I had to spend hours reading stuff up online afterwards to barely understand his notes.

There's a project as well, and the guidelines are vague (just apply some concepts from class to evaluate an engineering project). Still to this day I have no idea how technical/business focused it should be (some people did lots of calculations, others did detailed SWOT analysis) and how big the scope should be.

My main issue so far is that I can't understand a lot of their homework and exam questions (they are always written in confusing words).

If there's one topic I found particularly amusing, it would be the time the Professor spent half an hour showing us how to calculate our present worth (at least 5 million dollars or something). I still remember him preaching to us that "you are the most valuable investment."

Overall, a course with great potential (like I can see why we need to learn most of these topics). I think by fine tuning the content, it could be a very wonderful course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen is a very nice, kindhearted and inspirational guy. You can tell he truly cares about his students and wants us to learn new things in his class. He shares genuine stories like his experiences with debt and gives life advice. He will also answer any questions patiently in class even if they are dumb. I guess sometimes students send chat messages to doubt his rationale but he will just say "thank you for all your comments and suggestions". I really appreciate his effort and dedication in teaching.

And the problem: it's impossible to stay focused in his classes. He has a tendency to mumble in monotone (which definitely doesn't help explaining the already confusing concepts) and he mostly states the concepts without explaining in detail. What's worse is that he has iPRS every class which is absolutely a torture. His questions are just as confusing and we are only given a short time to answer them. Or maybe I'm just dumb, but most of the time I have to random guess the answers.

The TA, Joy, is very helpful most of the time. She replies to emails quickly and addresses our concerns almost instantly during the quizzes and final. She explains the practise and homework questions clearly as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes (17% each, total 2)
Project 25%
Final Exam 25%
5 Homework (Group) 15%
Class Participation (iPRS) 6%

As I mentioned the iPRS is quite confusing (it seems from the stats that a lot of people get them wrong), but the good news is that you can get half credit for wrong answers, and you can get back bonus points by asking questions during others' presentations.

The quizzes were not too hard (you should be able to complete most of it if you study) but the final was just ridiculously difficult. 20 questions (most of them are long calculation problems, only 2-3 MCQs) in an hour plus no returning to the previous questions.

The final project and exam marks were not released (I don't want to see them either, exam probably way below 50%) but I did decently well for the other parts (close to full mark for homework and mean +1SD for both quizzes) --> A range.

Giving grading an A from my overall feeling and since Professor mentioned that the A range is 22% of the class.
reviews.comment_workload:
Main workload is the project but it wasn't too much. Our group had around 3 short meetings and that was it. The final deliverable is only a 15 slide PowerPoint and a presentation, no report. Homework is also done in groups so each person only needs to attempt 1-2 questions.

Not exactly workload, but frequency of iPRS and peer evaluation in this course is unusually high (multiple iPRS questions in one class, one iPeer per homework and 2 more for project, many many iPRS for peer evaluating other groups during presentations).

reviews.author: C.C
reviews.title: good classmates light weight accounting course
reviews.comment_content:
§ Introduction to Engineering Economy
§ Cost Concepts and Design Economics
§ Cost-Estimation Techniques
§ The Time Value of Money
§ Evaluating a Single Project
§ Comparison and Selection among Alternatives
§ Depreciation and Income Taxes
§ Price Changes and Exchange Rates
§ Evaluating Projects with the Benefit-Cost Ratio Method
§ Dealing with Uncertainty
§ Portfolio Management

Not super interesting. The most important thing I learned is time value of money and taxes. You'll do lots of accounting in this course and you'll have to use tons of formulas.

There're however many good looking classmates in this course and boy:girl is around 1:1 which is most balanced in seng? (if that matters)

Also there's a group project + presentation and you can form group with whoever you want. The class was pretty lively on group presentation day.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There's 3% participation bonus and no lecture video, so you'll be penalized for skipping lecture. Moreover, maybe it's just me but very often I don't understand what the HW questions are actually asking and what do they want, even after reading the marking scheme my reaction is : how come ? why do you answer like that ?

But otherwise there's no big problem. They did reply email fast and they were helpful answering question.

By the way since there's no lecture video, I recommend this very useful youtube channel instead when doing revision https://youtube.com/@EngineeringEconomicsGuy

grade: B

I thought I'd get high mark in mid term so back then I didn't know why I score so low, I was disappointed and didn't go to paper check. But later (after final exam) I found out may be they didn't mark my MC because I answered the MC on question paper instead of answer paper (which is just a sheet of white paper, how am I supposed to answer MC there...). So make sure you ask for clarification right away and go to paper check if something don't make sense.

You can also see grading isn't very transparent, there's no appeal session for final exam either.

Nevertheless, I didn't work so hard in this course so I'm not super sad with this grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Actual workload is quite light. I only spend a night studying for exams. Overall I spent ~50 hrs in this course over the whole semester.

But I give B because I'm not very interested and so more effort is require to study.
